Comment: Hi Lizzy! I'm Pablito the curator of Mantastic. I really appreciate you mentioning the show even if it has a little sarcasm attached to it. I want to take the time to explain the mission of my show so you have a little more clarification. MANTASTIC NW is a select group of Portland based artists who celebrate the male form and body acceptance through visual art. As a collective of artists, our goal is to enrich the lives of people with our art and events. We are of the belief that art has a disproportionate amount of female figures compared to men, especially in nude forms. We are influenced by cultures that shame men for being bald, fat or hairy. We are also told that our genitals are shameful or inadequate. Mantastic NW is a group art show that wants to celebrate the male form and raise awareness of this gender bias within the art community and body shaming within the queer community. We are hoping to expand this show to women, POC and transgendered people who create male form art.

Comment: The Halifax case hinged on consent. If proper consent was given then there is no crime. Period, end of story. The complainant was extraordinarily honest and said she could not remember if she gave consent or not so there is no evidence that whatever acts occurred were without consent. 
There are only two other ways to get a guilty verdict after that:
The 1st is to say that she was in such a state that she could not legally give consent. That would require knowing her condition at the time. The last people to see her said she was under her own power, talking and making decisions on her own. So no proof she was unable to give consent.
The 2nd would be if she passed out and the sex continued after that. No one can know if that was in fact what happened since she cannot remember and there were no witnesses at the time of the sex.

Before putting anyone in prison for years you need to be very sure they're guilty. The court wasn't that sure and acted appropriately.

Comment: When I was a child growing up in Montreal, my parents would take my brothers, sisters and I to visit reserves.  We would stop and mingle with the people.  When I was in my early twenties and going to university, one classmate was a Mohawk.  We became good friends.  I ended up living with him and his family on a reserve in Ontario for two years.  It was a wonderful experience, because it taught me so much about the First Nations. I then went to live in China where I taught for twenty years. Having experienced life in another culture, I was able to adapt to life in the Middle Kingdom. Twenty years later, when I returned to Canada, a different Canada than the one I had left, I moved to an area where there are at least 12 reserves.  I have come full circle, and still my love of the First Nations has not changed. What has changed is my attitude towards white Canadians who have made no attempt to befriend and to experience first hand what it's like to know the people of the First Nations.

Comment: The problem with direct Chinese investment in Canadian corporations , is that direct investment is not a reciprocal arrangement between countries. As a Canadian businessman and investor I cannot directly invest in A Chinese domiciled business. I would need to do that in conjunction with a Chinese national .
Although possible , the process is fraught with risk, as control over everything remains with the local partner.
Until this changes I think allowing Chinese direct investment in Canada will be seen as a mistake in future years.

Comment: Hawaii doesn't get that hot.  The difference between hot and cool, is whether you have shade or not -- even for the buildings.  If they are in the sun all day, they soak up the heat and then radiate it out when it is cooler -- so that it never really effectively cools down.  The building itself is retaining the heat -- and absorbing it.

What you have to do is create shade -- by using mesh netting supported by a skeleton/suspension above the buildings and even campus walkways so that the sunlight doesn't ever touch the buildings.  That netting can be produced by recycling plastic bottles.  Such netting is in wide use in nurseries and athletic fields.  You could even stretch one over Aloha Stadium so the long suffering fans don't have to sit on scalding hot seats while letting in the breeze..  At least the fans and players can remain comfortable.

It's the perfect material/technology for Hawaii.  You're surrounded by the ocean -- and not desert.  That temperature is optimal 70.  Use it.

Apparently one cannot know from this study because there is no control arm.

Comment: I remember the Ghomeshi case quite well and it wouldn't be fair to say he was innocent of any wrongdoing. He was found not guilty at the first trial, and prior to the second trial the complainant agreed to forgo the proceedings if Ghomeshi would issue a formal apology for his behavior, which he did. 

In the case before us now, Justice Camp was not alleged to have committed an offence. He simply didn't do his job the way it needed to be done. He freely and openly admits his errors in thinking concerning sexual assault law and has taken concrete steps to rectify the deficiency.

Despite those striking differences, it's interesting to note that the outcome for both Ghomeshi and Camp are quite similar. Both have been publicly vilified and their careers destroyed. I submit that the similarity in outcome is evidence that the public and its institutions fail to keep a balanced perspective when allegations of male-on-female sexism are made.

Comment: It's more problematic that we feel compelled to inject our personal politics into every corner of our lives. At its crudest level it simply means sanctioning everyone and everything you disagree with or makes you feel uncomfortable--as if "the other" was somehow automatically in the wrong or even inherently evil.

It's ironic that so-called progressives aggressively accuse so-called right-wingers of being biased and intolerant: they're no different. The only difference is the degree of blinkered self-righteousness and groupthink: progressives dominate the media and academia--for the moment--so they've convinced themselves that they're on the right side of history and morality. But they're as black-and-white in their views on issues as they accuse conservatives of being.

It's a question of attitude, not of some set of absolutes that someone has a corner on. As long as we politicize everything, society will be divided into us and them, and aggression and fear will continue to rule.

Comment: I find it hard to comprehend that online streaming services such as YouTube are the cause of or even a major contributor to starving our artists.  I can appreciate the struggle that may be apparent, in that YouTube does provide a platform where content, original or otherwise, can be streamed without payment from a user. However, artists will only be compensated to a level of their popularity.  As an artist, you make choices as to what you choose to create.  If your product is one which is desirable, compensation for it comes quickly & naturally.  If the product you create has a limited market, compensation can only reach as far as a target group who care for it.  YouTube has allowed many people with no access to professional channels to become quite wealthy by creating content which people want to view.  I believe in the cases where an artist stays true to the art they want to make, they must accept it may not be appreciated by the masses, and therefore not be profitable.

Comment: @Donnie: Arrearage is most certainly NOT a Republican issue. @Alan: Randy did not bring up arrearage inappropriately. It became an issue during the primary in response to questions from citizens. Comment: The powers that the Senate is starting to properly exercise are not only their right, but their legislated responsibility under the Constitution. I'm glad to see the current members, by and large, doing their job so ably.

However, I wish Mr. Ibbitson and those so-called constitutional experts would finally stop prattling about how the House has more "legitimacy" because it is elected. That presumption is wrong. The Constitution and the legislation it enables stipulates that appointment to the House is by election whereas appointment to the Senate is by the Governor-General of Canada upon the recommendation of the sitting Prime Minister of Canada. You cannot get any more legitimate than the legally-stipuated requirements and process.

That said, I much prefer the nomination process that was recently initiated, so that merit and service to the country is properly considered.

Comment: I agree that leaving money in RRIF can be problematic from the standpoint that the final pot is taxed at potentially max marginal tax rate on death of second spouse.

This issue can be even a bigger problem if one spouse dies relatively early.  Their RRIF is rolled into the second spouses and than the amount required to be withdrawn is now taken by one spouse and taxed at a higher marginal tax rate.

I am not a huge fan of RRSP/RRIF for this reason.  I think people need to consider the tax deduction vs taxes paid.  They work best for one spouse who has very high income and other spouse does not work so future withdrawals will be done at lower marginal tax rate.  

TFSA in my opinion should be preferred method of retirement savings for most middle income earners.  However don't spend it for a kitchen upgrade.  If you can save more than TFSA allows, some amount in RRSP should not be a problem.

Most do not think about withdrawal strategy.  They are lured by that shiny tax deduction.

Comment: I own a number of stocks on both lists (in addition to several more).  My portfolio includes many stocks that are textbook examples of classic dividend stocks.  Modest yield with steady and seemingly predictable dividend increases.  These form the bedrock of my portfolio.  From there I own a number of stocks that pay higher yields from the 5% - 10%+ range.  But the trade off isn't sustainability or high yield - it is usually dividend growth vs. high yield.  In other words the business model is set up to flow a greater proportion of cash through to the owners vs reinvestment.   That business model may indeed come with a higher level of risk (and usually does), but not necessarily in a disproportionate manner.  Although those inclined to monitor their stock prices by the hour admittedly probably wouldn't have the stomach for some of the names.

High yield investments don't equate to impaired investments.  A shift over time to high yield may be an indicator of impaired investments.

Comment: Donald Trump owes his victory in the Electoral College to three states he won by the smallest number of votes: Pennsylvania, Wisconsin, and Michigan. According to the latest tallies, Trump won Pennsylvania by 1.1 percentage points (68,236 votes), Wisconsin by 0.9 points (27,257 votes), Michigan by 0.2 points (11,837 votes). If Clinton had won all three states, she would have won the Electoral College 278 to 260. She fell short in all three, of course, and that's why we are now getting accustomed to the reality of President-elect Donald J. Trump.

Comment: There are a few things wrong here. First, science denialism has no political affiliation. There are plenty of ideas dear to the political left that make fine examples of science denialism, and these ideas range from the denial of the role of biology on human behavior (just like religionists') to permitting the spread of malaria. Secondly, science relies mostly on inductive and abductive reasoning, and as such, "the unknowns" are not known, and this is why facts can be revised over time. While the components of a model may proven, the logical entailments between them can be lacking. Also, the peer review process may have been at one time what Mr. Box describes, but that is no longer the case, there is a lot of inducement in the current enterprise of science to lead scientists to collude. Lastly, peer review is the collection of opinions, so science is a matter concerning opinion, just like critiques of math proofs asserted to answer difficult mathematical problems.

Comment: t should go without saying that Arpaio is a terrible candidate for a pardon. 

If you have any doubts, read this chilling 2009 profile of Arpaio by William Finnegan in The New Yorker. 

Arpaio’s first claim to local fame was to make the conditions of imprisonment for inmates under his jurisdiction as inhumane as possible — housing thousands of people in tents next to cites like dumps and waste disposal plants in the brutal Arizona heat. 

He fed inmates for 30 cents a meal, two meals a day, and then made the Food Network one of three channels available to prisoners. 

He put many people who were being held for trial and had not been convicted of any crime to work on chain gangs. 

Under his watch, guards were so consistently cruel to inmates that the county had amassed more than $40 million in civil damages from lawsuits. 

And he also engaged in egregious racial profiling when detaining people suspected of being illegal immigrants.

Comment: "...he was told to publicly revise some of [his] views...."

A person, such as Tony Flannery, thinks sincerely about important things and arrives at ideas, conclusions, and questions. Then a person in authority tells him to say publicly that those are not his thoughts. What exactly does the authority think is accomplished? That threatening someone until he mouths a lie is a moral act? That using threats and force to get such a statement is equivalent to the person changing his held, concluded ideas? That other people will be convinced by such a counterfeit, feigned makeover? The utter pettiness and triviality of the authority is what stands out here, the veniality and pompous arrogance, the valuing of surface over substance and depth. Do the authorities making this demand really imagine in this situation that anyone has been convinced by them? If they do, what shallow fools they are; if not, what malicious and torturing tyrants.

Comment: There are many more deaths by drowning in backyard pools in places with more... wait for it... backyard pools.

People determined to kill themselves, as opposed to cry for help, will choose the most lethal method available, and the US has a much lower suicide rate than most countries with more restrictive gun laws. So gun ownership lacks any correlation, much less causation, to suicide in any actually meaningful way.

And, of course, most gun suicides (as in something like 90+%) are middle-aged, predominently male, gun owners so no realistic gun restriction can rationally have any effect. They already own the guns, and can pass background checks to buy one if not. Most serious suicides plan their deaths, so waiting periods are useless (they'll wait or substitute). As adults they have access to even a "safe-storage law" gun and ammunition. Only one shot is needed so any gun can work, even a flintlock musket, so semi-auto, pistol, mag capacity, etc bans can't help.

Comment: Paul, in some ways I wish we still lived in the world you describe. My oldest niece used to live in a small town in Alaska. A while back I told her that, having lived in a number of small towns growing up -- my parents moved a lot -- I was kind of nostalgic about them. And I had wondered, considering my leftist politics, if I would be accepted in a small town. She said people in her town wouldn't care about my politics. What they would care about, she said, is whether I would volunteer. Apparently the town depended a lot on volunteers for mutual survival. 

Well I do volunteer, working on the homeless issue, and so do a lot of the other advocates, as well as some of the homeless themselves. But I'm afraid that a lot of that mutual support has been lost to people's busy lives and social indifference.

On the effect of economic change on community support, I recommend "Our Kids: The American Dream in Crisis" by Robert Putnam.

Comment: I dunno.....

Why do people comment on subjects they don't have a clue about?

CRS 18-6-401. Child abuse
(1) (a) A person commits child abuse if such person causes an injury to a child's life or health, or permits a child to be unreasonably placed in a situation that poses a threat of injury to the child's life or health,...
...
(7) (a) Where death or injury results, the following shall apply:
(I) When a person acts knowingly or recklessly and the child abuse results in death to the child, it is a class 2 felony except as provided in paragraph (c) of this subsection (7).
(II) When a person acts with criminal negligence and the child abuse results in death to the child, it is a class 3 felony.
(III) When a person acts knowingly or recklessly and the child abuse results in serious bodily injury to the child, it is a class 3 felony.
(IV) When a person acts with criminal negligence and the child abuse results in serious bodily injury to the child, it is a class 4 felony.

Comment: I want to both agree and disagree with some of what both brothers say. I agree with Ivo that I also believe there is no God - I'm an atheist.

But in support of the brother Onne I want to draw on the inspiration of Alain de Botton in "Religion for Atheists.

From www-archive.biblesociety.org.au/news/review-religion-for-atheists I quote the following:
"De Botton draws on the Old Testament book of Job as a means of contemplating our own insignificance in the face of the size and mystery of the universe and the awesome fact of existence. He argues for a secular space where we are able to meditate on our smallness and avert the sense that we are the psychological center of all things and the masters of our destinies. De Botton laments the tendency of modern life to trample on the rhythms of the earth, to deny death and shy away from the harsh edges of reality."

Non-believers can learn a lot from religion, without having to give up atheism.

Comment: I have two problems with buying the F-35.

1) We need more than 65 planes. It does not matter that they may be more lethal than others and that we wouldn't need a training squadron. We have a lot of territory to cover.
2) While touted as a multi-role plane (reconnaissance, strike, air superiority) I think it is really for strike purposes. Close air support and air superiority isn't its strong suit. The U.S. intends on using this plane side by side with F-22 Raptors and F/A-18E Super Hornets or F-15SA Eagles for air cover. We won't have those aircraft.

The Saab Gripen E is a new design (not in production) that is also a multi-role aircraft, but its emphasis is on air superiority, reconnaissance, and the strike. It is cheaper too, meaning we can buy more for our money. We could also manufacture the plane under license in Montreal (or wherever) instead of keeping production lines going in the States.

Comment: The long standing rule relating to circumstantial evidence in criminal cases is the rule in Hodge's case. I don't recall the exact words, but the general idea is that before you can convict solely on circumstantial evidence, that evidence must be not only consistent with guilt but inconsistent with any innocent explanation.  In this case, "consent" is a possible innocent explanation.

Comment: Converting PS pension lans to DC would not save the employer a single penny and l;eave retirees poorer - a lose lose situation. DC also costs more for an employer to manage as there are separate accounts for every employee rather than a pooled amount. That also makes long term investing harder.

Comment: I wonder if Brown or any of the commentators below know that once electricity is generated, it cannot be stored.     It's not like there is a bin of electricity waiting to be sold or an inventory of electricity.    It's produced and consumed instantly and any excess demand must be met by buying electricity and any excess supply sold - all done immediately at whatever the price is on the trading market by the independent system operator to maintain system balance.      If this wasn't done, you would see brownouts and energy spikes constantly.     The nature of the market means that spot prices are incredibly volatile.    And remember that generation cannot be spun up instantaneously - whereas demand can come on and off at any time.    

There is a lot to criticize Ontario for on the electricity side, but Brown making an issue of this one day's trading is kind of sleazy (unless he truly does not know better) and relies upon total ignorance about the trading  market to succeed.

Comment: Amazing, isn't it! I knew that this total solar eclipse was going to be a big deal years ago, but the interest has exceeded my expectations. Given that Madras, Redmond, Bend and even the Warm Springs Reservation lodging space is full, you can imagine how full the other places along the mid-path are, such as Jackson and Casper, Wyoming.  All camping space in Oregon state parks anywhere along the path are long gone. Oregon Parks decided to make more space available in parks, just for the event, and those were all taken within 15 minutes of when they opened for reservations. Get eclipse glasses, before they are all gone, and enjoy the partial. BTW, the Science Factory shop has the glasses for less than $2.

INTRODUCTION
According to the 2010 Census, 1.2 million people in the United States identified as Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander, either alone or in combination with one or more other races. The Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander population was the race group most 
likely to report multiple races in 2010, as more than half (56 percent) 
reported multiple races. The Native Hawaiian and Other Pacific Islander 
population was one of the fastest- growing race between 2000 and 2010.

Comment: That carbon dioxide is a greenhouse gas was established in the 19th century. No one who knows anything about it disputes this.

The industrial revolution started around 1750 with the twin inventions of the Watt's steam engine (which made the earlier version practical) and Arkwright's spinning jenny (which mechanized the textile industry), is thoroughly accepted as valid in the climatological community -- that the proportion of CO2 in the atmosphere was 280 parts per million. There is evidence that number was essentially constant for the last ten thousand years. The current value is 399 ppm. 

Now, you are claiming that carbon dioxide is not a greenhouse gas (and don't give us this "I don't know for certain", you are flat-out saying "it's not") and that a 40% increase in the CO2 content in the atmosphere is meaningless. Further, you are sneering at scientists because they work for the government -- which is the worst sort of conservative stupidity.

Comment: Part 2

Archbishop Lefebvre wrote in Religious Liberty Questioned: 

all of this is based on the Church's fundamental principles, on the fact that the Church is truth, the only truth. This is the way it is; you either believe it or you don't, of course, but when you believe, then you have to draw the consequences. That is why, personally, I do not believe that the declarations of the Council on liberty of conscience, liberty of thought, and liberty of religion can be compatible with what the popes taught in the past. Therefore we have to choose. Either we choose what the popes have taught for centuries and we choose the Church or we choose what was said by the Council. But we cannot choose both at the same time since they are contradictory. 

Nope, the schismatic Lefebvre rejected Dignitatis Humanae. He was right about one thing, however: DH flatly contradicts what Pius IX said about freedom of religion.

Comment: Single payer meets both the moral requirement and the fiscal requirement: it guarantees healthcare to all, free on demand, while at the same time saving the vast majority of US residents money and saving the government money as well. The only objection to a medicare for all system comes from people who think that others deserve to suffer, that people deserves to be denied potentially life-saving care because they don't meet certain requirements. This is a vicious, cruel position that should not be entertained. That fact is that if we approach this from a position of either humanitarian interest or self interest, single payer becomes the only viable option. It saves us money, it guarantees us care, and it guarantees our neighbors care as well. If you care about yourself, support single payer. If you care about your neighbor, support single payer. If you want other people to suffer even at the expense of your own wallet and well-being, your opinion doesn't matter.

Comment: I am not exaggerating or speaking untruths, I have done my research. I have also experienced the US system firsthand as a person with a rare genetic disease, three other chronic illnesses, and a resulting physical disability. I've lived in the US, Germany, & Austria, & the insurance coverage/healthcare available to me in the other two countries was far better than what I received in the US. I fell under the "pre-existing conditions" category before the ACA was passed, and was denied insurance by practically every carrier. The insurance options that the ACA opened up made it possible for me to afford my much needed medications and procedures, & even then my medical expenses were exorbitant. A 3-day hospital stay in the US cost me over 20x more than three weeks in a German hospital. The copay for a specialist's visit was 10x more in the US than Austria. I was denied an MRI to find a clot doctors knew was in my brain because it was too expensive and I wasn't actively bleeding.

Comment: Suggestions made previously, maybe worth repeating:

1. Have Ottawa demand that Quebec END its investor immigrant program, a program that brings in the better part of ten thousand new super-rich immigrants a year, who then go on to buy houses in Toronto and Vancouver. 

2. Have Ottawa BAN the purchase of detached houses in Canada by foreign students on student visas. There is NO compelling reason for allowing college and university students from overseas to function as proxy house buyers for their millionaire parents in end-runs around our foreign purchase laws. 

3. Have Ottawa pick Vancouver and Toronto as test cities for a new program where, unless you work locally (or have worked in Canada for ten years), your property tax rate is 20 percent of house price per year.

Comment: I know a few brilliant and successful people that were home schooled.  But for every one of that type, there are probably 50-100 that have problems throughout life because they never got their social interaction skills figured out as a kid.  As the saying goes, some of the most important things you learn in (public) school is what you learn between classes.  You learn to deal with difficult people, mean people, manipulative people, peer pressure and hormones.  Most home schoolers are stunted in learning these tools for survival.  And they often go on to live troubled lives.  Our society was much less disfunctional 40 years ago when everyone went to real schools.

Comment: The ridership simply isn't there to support an LRT.  The Beeline route, which will be replaced by the LRT, is currently the only profitable route for the HSR, and it only has 1/4 of the ridership required to make the LRT cost effective.  Once the LRT is built it is totally inflexible, whereas buses can be added and removed as needed.  In addtion, the LRT only saves 4 to 5 minutes over the bus, but people will be walking an extra 10 to 15 minutes to get on it - making commute by public transit even longer and pretty miserable in inclement weather.
Not to mention, the increase in property taxes surrounding the LRT will force lower income people out of the area due to rising rents to compensate for the increase in property taxes.  
In addition, no arrangements have been made for courier companies to deliver to businesses - many do not have any delivery access other than their front door.

Comment: You have the wrong Charter section and are entirely missing the point. You are referring to s. 10(b). The section applicable in this case is 11(b) "Any person charged with an offence has the right: (b) to be tried within a reasonable time". 

In this case, Curtis's lawyer is not available at an early date, and so Curtis is deemed to have waived his right to a prompt trial. However, co-accused's Corey's lawyer is available and ready to proceed promptly. The crown insists on trying the two together. The question that arises is whether Curtis's waiver of the Jordan time limit can be applied to Corey.

The obvious answer is to sever the indictment and proceed promptly to try Corey, and try Curtis separately when his lawyer is available.

Comment: Bob,

We need to ensure that wolves remain visible and viable, this is especially important within Denali National Park. What is Alaska without these predators? It is no longer wild, it is a farm for ungulates.

Comment: In the aftermath of the devastating 2013 Calgary flood, there was a wonderful article by a U of C professor published in the Calgary Herald that was titled "A Flood Plain is a Plain That Floods". I personally know a number of people who experienced extreme flood damage during that disaster and other floods during this century and they all had one thing in common; they lived on the flood plain. Flood plains are wonderful places to live and recreate when the river is not flooding. Cities, municipalities, provinces and home owners continue to invest large sums of money along rivers and lakes in almost total disregard of the fact that flooding will occur at some point in the future. When the flooding does occur, many "experts" blame climate change, and the victims expect the government to bail them out. These bail outs are subsidies whereby the majority of society that does not build on flood plains bails out the minority that does. Remember, a flood plain is a plain that floods.

Comment: I'm not convinced of your argument Timber Wolf.

First, there's no evidence to support it.  Second, how do you even measure quality of legal services? Third, you can say "quality vs. quantity" about any profession.  If you're going to use that argument to keep the number of lawyers low, how about car mechanics and cooks and truck drivers?  Low quality in those occupations will cause fatalities. 

Also I never said "excess"; and I don't what that means in this situation.  In a market economy, supply and demand meet to determine a market price that satisfies the majority of buyers and also provides the sellers with enough profit to continue.  Excesses sort themselves out (e.g., lawyers/paralegals who don't make enough money will go do something else).

To solve this issue of delays in the courts, requires curing the disease not the symptom.  Do we agree on that?

Comment: This  reminds me of when I was a student in a "Problems of Democracy" class at Marshfield High School back in 1953.  As a class project, two of us  took  extracts from the  Declaration of Independence, placed them on a petition, and went door to door in Coos Bay-
As I recall, the sections we included were:
"whenever any form of government becomes destructive to these ends, it is the right of the people to alter or to abolish it, and to institute new government, laying its foundation on such principles, and organizing its powers in such forms, as to them shall seem most likely to effect their safety and happiness."
Also:
"But when a long train of abuses and usurpations, pursuing invariably the same object, evinces a design to reduce them under absolute despotism, it is their right, it is their duty, to throw off such government, and to provide new guards for their future security."
Almost nobody signed, and  the resulting newspaper headline was "THOMAS JEFFERSON DECLARED COMMUNIST."

Comment: No doubt that the Pharma industry contributed to physician over prescribing of opioids...which has contributed to the current opioid epidemic.  However, there are some safeguards with opioid registries and more stringent control of opioid dispensing by pharmacies that are demonstrating some improvements.   Opioid prescribing should be responsible.  Medical schools have added this to their curriculums.  "Chronic pain" is a heterogenous collection of patients with all sorts of disabling conditions.  Chronic degenerative conditions often associated with neuropathic pain can benefit from opioid therapy when other therapies have not worked well.  These patients must be remembered when developing future strategies that address the problems of chronic pain and addiction.  For these patients, regular opioid therapy under supervision is associated with addiction risk of less than 4%.  That risk is still high, but when given the choice, patients choose to tackle their pain.

To think freely and critically is not something one can do on their own, but rather they need a tradition, a historical tradition minds you, to cultivate. Comment: There is no doubt that as a performance art, a valid Catholic ordination is not a requirement for good preaching or good liturgy. 

The arguments involve beliefs about the divinely established differences between man and woman, the nature of the origin of Holy Orders, and the notion of Christ as the High Priest described in Hebrews of which the earthly priest is the "alter Christus" in the Eucharist's anamnesis of that one perfect Sacrifice.

All three of those beliefs were rejected by the Episcopal Church beginning in the 1970s, by the Lutheran Church of Sweden in the 1960s, and of course by many other Protestant denominations.

Episcopalians who hew to the former beliefs wound up in "continuing churches" or, in rare cases such as the Episcopal Diocese of South Carolina in a diocese which exited the Episcopal Church.

Not all of the Anglican Communion sees eye-to-eye with the Episcopal Church, and as of late 2015 it is under what is effectively a three-year suspension.

Comment: Broadly, you're right on the money that there are some industries that require significant infrastructure that we simply don't yet have in Alaska. There are, however, industries that would do just fine here. IT/software is something you can do anywhere. Industries that require little-to-no physical infrastructure are where we want to start. One or two people developing a mobile app simply need access to a computer, and the ability to upload their code to a remote (e.g. Amazon) server that, in turn, distributes the app to global customers (via CDN servers). We also have uniquely concentrated expertise in Alaska that gives us an edge over other places. Energy and support experts are a good example. Defense industry expertise is another, both active and the many who have retired and decided to call Alaska home (e.g. dual use drones; we're already doing great university-connected UAV work). We can't start doing everything here, but we do have some very good places we can start.

Comment: Hey Mark, By the way, I never said I condoned cruelty to animals. I, however, do not believe it is a sin to eat meat, although it should not be eaten every day - perhaps once or twice a week. As a Catholic, I have fasted from meat every Friday for years now, not only during Lent, the whole year. For the last 5 years now, I have also participated through a Catholic Church group in a strict fast the first week of Lent (starting Ash Wednesday) of not eating anything  for 7 days. We only drink non-carbonated water - no juices, etc. It's not easy but we meet for Holy Mass every evening and then sit in a group and discuss a theme (topic) that the Pastor has decided on in advance. This year it was the 100th Anniversary of Fatima. During this week, we also have an evening of Adoration of the Most Blessed Sacrament and the opportunity to Confess. Going to daily Mass and Confession, Adoration, praying the Rosary often, help my decision-making. I'm more in tune to sinning. Conscience very alert!

Comment: sterling is not so sterling in his arguments.  first, funding rail using bonds will only drive up the cost of rail.  and as more bond funding is used by the city, the city's bond rating goes down and rates go up.  in the end the bonds will have to be paid back, this will place the burden on future generation.

his argument about sunk costs are circular.  completing rail in light of increasing costs is not throwing good money after bad.  rail is a vital component of Oahu's future, providing mass transit, affordable housing, quality of life for residents, etc .  most long term projects have cost overruns, but the trick is to deal with them the most efficient way.  the notion that cost overruns are inevitable so we should not attempt to build things is ridiculous.  

third, that only people that benefit from rail should pay for it - this is misguided.  there have been many projects, nationally and locally, that are funded by funds provided by people other that do not have direct benefit.

Comment: Not really. This whole issue is not about shifting from neutral to a position of bias.  Is about police not dismissing claims from the outset (as they have had a general propensity to do) and believing that a complaint "may" have merit at the outset.  This is not bias.  It only becomes bias if the belief that it may have merit prejudices the investigation.  My point (which I thought was pretty clear) is that a good investigator is required to conduct a neutral investigation and follow the evidence...regardless of what that evidence shows.

It is true that the system needs to make sure that investigators are neutral, and that decisions are made on evidence, regardless of whether it is inculpatory or exculpatory.  This is the investigator's job, and this whole issue surrounds the question about whether they are doing this and about whether they are properly trained.

Comment: Depends on the job, and who normally does that sort of work.

One academic paper on the topic I read 20 years ago posited the notion of "the competent incumbent" in hiring decisions, and assessment of male and female applicants.  If the job-type was predominantly male, OR female, the mental image of the competent incumbent would be bound up with gender stereotypes, such that the one gender or the other would be perceived more favorably (call up your notion of what a firefighter looks like).  Not any sort of "We don't want your kind here" bias.  Rather those candidates simply *seemed* more capable or qualified.

As the gender balance in the workplace shifted (and I seem to recall the tipping point was around 1/3 or more of the under-represented sex), gender-stereotypes entered into the mental image of competent incumbent less.

Comment: Please consider the impact on the town. King county has become a Mecca for the homeless because of the shelters and services provided. Of course we want to help those in need, but when the only criteria for the shelter is homelessness, you are welcoming dangerous individuals to your community and inviting drug abuse and crime. 
If you truly want to help, stop enabling behaviors that put them at risk and require drug testing and check for warrants for the safety of the community and residents of the shelter. Provide counseling and job training. 
Look around you, study the impact of providing shelter with no other requirement than homelessness. Providing temporary shelter is a temporary fix. Help people help themselves, provide job search training and employability skills. Require able bodied individuals to attend classes or actively seek employment. Work towards solving the problem rather than perpetuating it.

When you shop , do you offer to pay 20 percent or more for everything or do you buy from who gives you the best price and backs up what they sell ? Comment: William:  I've been a hunter all my life.  Started in the 1950s with my Grandfather.  I still own guns, though I no longer hunt.  We live in rural Lane County are are content to watch the deer and wild turkeys (sometimes too many turkeys) in our yard and orchard.  I have no problem with others who hunt and sports-shoot.  Usually, they're very careful with their firearms and are not a threat to anyone.  I am concerned with the proliferation of semi-automatic, large magazine rifles among the general population.  I am concerned with the ease with which virtually anyone can buy a gun today.....legit market and black market.  I feel there are some very reasonable efforts to try to keep firearms away from dangerous individuals.....via expanded background checks and the use of the "no-fly" and/or watch list....the NRA has consistently opposed all of these.  I don't see that as reasonable....

I don't want to "take away" everyone's guns.  However, lets be frank..some people shouldn't have them

Comment: barjona, I did not suggest that the idea that biology plays a role is hateful. So I'm afraid I can't explain that to you.

I am not dismissing Damore's memo completely. Indeed, I said I admire his attempt! Some of what he says I agree with, some of it I don't. For instance, I agree with his suggestion of making computing be more about people (see Michael Sean Mahoney's work on the history of why computer science was created as a mathematical discipline: because it raised the status of computer scientists). But he does ignore a key area, which is history. Scientific theory is all very well, but you have to look at what has actually *happened*.

Comment: The telescopes do not "charge" thousands of dollars. No money changes hands that way. It is true that they cost thousands per night to operate. This funding comes from many sources, most of it federal grants, allocated to the partners. Time is allocated on the telescopes by a public proposal process and peer review. Generally, only 20-30% of applicants actually receive time. No astronomer is "charged" for time. It is not a commercial enterprise. I have had hundreds of nights on telescopes around the world and in space. I have never been billed for any of it.

Comment: The skyrocketing premiums are mostly from Red States whose governors said they will opt out of the pool and use the monies from the federal program, Medicaid. Once the federal monies dry out, these Red States are refusing to supplement the premium fees, like the other states that are, or from the other states that have participated in the pool. 

Hawai'i does not participate in the pool anymore because the state law makes it mandatory for all workers to have minimal health coverage if they work at least 20 hrs a week. The rest of the people goes into the medicaid program. Independent contractors have to buy insurance or get penalized.  There are subsidies from the fed gov, but those will dry up in the future. Yes nothing is free for the majority of tax payers, for those people unable to pay taxes or not working, I believe the society has to provide care for them, with the idea that we all can get help when and if its our time to do so.

Comment: What is a business?  A business provides a product, item, software, service to customers for a price.  The core element of a business is the product.  I learned this through starting several venture capital funded companies.  The first and foremost element necessary for a viable startup company is a product idea.  The closer the idea is to shippable product the better.  What holds Eugene back is 1) lack of large market product ideas, and 2) the lack of resident people with skills necessary to produce a finished product and reach national and international markets.  It does not matter what the "entrepreneurship" promoters say.  Brilliant product and access to large market are the only key elements.  Eugene  problems include the reluctance of talented outside people to start a business here because of perceptions that Eugene is not business friendly, and Oregon's relatively high personal income tax which founders and employees who come here will have to pay, etc.

Bullying is bullying - whether you do it yourself or you let your dog do it for you. And this probably could have been avoided if you'd simply installed a 4-foot fence that let people know where the boundaries were instead of an electronic fence that left control up to the imagination.

Comment: Couple of things to point out:

Cost-when you add back "the cost of advice" into the total fee of ETF's they cheaper compared to MF however the gap closes. I'm referencing full service advice.NotROBO

Broker-Grids at the major brokerage houses are forcing brokers to buy ETF's as the cost or starting point of the  ETF fee is low enough that they can charge 1.5-1.8% advice fee - this fee needs to be charged as it is mandated (at some firms) + the the grid (payout) at most of the major brokerage firms is only 50% and therefore if they are charging 1.5-1.8% they are getting 75/90bps in commission (most brokers won't get a 50% payout) at the high end. Compare that with a MF F series who's starting point is around 90-100bps then add on the commission of 1.5% to 1.8% and the cost is much higher compared to a MF with with embedded comp of just 1%  so the math does not work hence why they sell ETF's and one of the major reasons (at least on the advice side) that they have taken off.

Comment: U.S. Healthcare does cost more than in other nations.  But, single payer is not the primary reason.  Cost of living and average incomes play major roles.  For example, in the U.S. the average income of an Orthopedic Surgeon is $442,450.  A Canadian Orthopedic Surgeon gets $208,000, less than half.  All other health care workers get less pay.  In fact, all Canadians make less.  That was a central point in a comparison of US and Canadian health care costs conducted by Canada's leading think tank, the Fraser Institute.  The found that after deducting our average health care costs, Americans made $6,000 more, per year, on average, than did Canadians.   Americans pay more for health care simply because we can afford to.  If we got the exact care Canadians get, your out of pocket drug costs would inrease, mental health services would be scarcer and people seeking gender reassignment would often be out in the cold.  Waiting lists are a scandal in Canada.  Is that what we really want?

That exposure in turn helps universities attract more applicants and increase tuition-paying enrollment, which in an era of reduced public support is their lifeblood financially.  It also increases alumni support and general public donations.  Beyond the marketing benefit, athletics enriches campus life for many students who enjoy attending games, and enables athletes who could not otherwise afford school to get a higher education.

Comment: Huh??? This is so innacurate and misleading.... let's explain the reality. They CAN'T ASK FOR PUNITIVE damages, per-se, as their complaint doesn't allege any direct harm on behalf of the defendant. Last time I checked, and for the last several hundred years of common-law application, that was still a prerequisite element to any type of puntitive entitlement. The fact is, compensatory damages are much more appealing, as they are not taxable like punitive damages. More importantly, in Colorado, any type of "injury" including an emotional injury can be levied against the liable party.
 To say that "Not seeking punitive damages, so the likelihood of a big payday is slim. Compensatory damages would be medical expenses and maybe lost wages if she missed any work. If she suffered permanent damage there could be damages for the disability" is entirely inaccurate, as the majority of the damages, comprising a large payday being sought, would fall in to the category of emotional injury.

Laminated beams and wafer board plywood (OSB) which is made from "scraps" now replaces much of the laminated plywood and solid beam needs.  Plastics and other materials have replaced a lot of wood products.  I'm not so sure the issue is settled by just opening-up the forests.

Comment: Re. "new texts, in addition to the old ones, to reflect a changing student body." How many new texts can you add before you start pushing out the old ones that have stood the test of time and are recognized as *literature*? And how do you know the new texts are not just ephemera added to satisfy political expediency? 
Cleansing the canon is old hat. In university English, it began in the 1980s, when Toni Morrison began displacing the great William Faulkner, because he dealt so frankly with race, albeit sympathetically. 
Re. "a school official reportedly said To Kill a Mockingbird may make some uncomfortable." The school official perhaps doesn't see that one of the main functions of literature is to make readers uncomfortable and to *criticize*: when one is uncomfortable, one thinks. The unfamiliar, not the familiar, makes us think. Heart of Darkness and 1984 made many of us very uncomfortable. Sadly, not much thinking results when students enter what amounts to a literary echo-chamber.

Comment: Thomas Square could use some love.  It would be great to see it refurbished.

The City has at least two options to fund an upgrade:
1) Commercialize the park to make some money, at the cost of restricting access to the public at certain times or places, or
2) Raise property taxes, at the cost of angering voters hostile to the kuleana of maintaining and improving public spaces in Honolulu's urban environment.

Option 1 expands rights of property at the expense of a benefit of citizenship--the right of person not to be denied access to the public space at Thomas Square.

Option 2 maintains the right of person by restricting property rights in the form of a higher tax on real property.

The City's plan favors property rights over rights of person, a process known to historians as enclosure.

Comment: Today's climate change is indeed caused by humans. The scientific understanding of it is nearly as good as our understanding of gravity. If you hold a ball in your hand and let it go, you can bet it will move downward. Similarly, if you add carbon dioxide to the atmosphere by burning fossil fuels, Earth's temperature will increase. The ongoing, abrupt increase in Earth's temperature differs markedly from the much slower increases caused by natural effects. People who purport to explain climate change as a natural climate variation are imposing their ignorance onto the public.

Comment: Appealing to authority, e.g. Nature, simply does not work in science because no matter how authoritative you are you can be wrong. Science responds to hard data.

All the data you mention does nothing to indicate the cause. For example, if the cause is due to women being more likely to take time off to start and raise a family and then finding it very hard to get back into science again having quotas will do nothing to address that. This is why science exists: when confronted with what looks like a possible problem we investigate to find whether there is a problem and what the cause is. 

Climate change is a perfect example of this. Confronted with data showing increasing global temperatures a huge research effort was launched which has shown that we are largely the cause. If the government response had been to rely on anecdotes about warm weather do you think anyone would have changed their minds and been motivated to take action?

Comment: I did trust NASA, in it's early days. However in keeping track of temperature records, as an old hobby, I noticed that old monthly & yearly averages were changing. On historical records, that opens the door to interpretation that can be used to skew data results. I can remember when adjusting past data, without noting as to when & why, was grounds for being escorted to the EXIT door.

In particular, data seemed to be regularly changing since the 1990's. After doing some digging, it seemed that older data seemed to decrease while new data points were adjusted upward. 

Only a bit later, I was informed that the data was being "homogenized".

Having worked with NASA people, on NASA projects, a few decades ago, it was a grave disappointment to see some of the practices at play.

Comment: While it can't be ruled out in every instance during this war, there's no reasonable scenario that would cause the Syrian government to target these civilians with chemical weapons. After all, the Syrian government spent YEARS trying to take back the critical city of Aleppo from the al-Nusrah terrorists, without resorting to the use of the chemical weapons. So the claim that they would use them against civilians in a non-strategic area simply does not make sense.

However, there is a straight-forward explanation for what happened. The al-Nusrah group that controls Idlib is known to have chemical weapons, including sarin. The UN has accused them of using it more than once during the war. If the Syrian jets targeted an al-Nusrah weapons cache containing the sarin, it could be dispersed widely enough to kill civilians.

Comment: IMO,  Doyle is muddying the argument here. 
Television may still be important and relevant - that doesn't mean the CBC is. 
You cannot simply declare certain CBC shows to be "high quality" or "entertaining". 
The consumer is the judge - hence the obsession with ratings. 

The CBC will simply have to re-invent itself as it will never have enough taxpayer money, nor should it, to compete with major networks. 
A PBS - style format would be one such model. 
Perhaps there are others.
But.
This re-invention cannot take place unless the CBC drops their inflated sense of self-importance. 
The pompous "we make shows that we've decided you should watch" attitude needs to go

How about searching for a niche that isn't being satisfied? 
Personally,  I'd be OK parting with a few tax dollars in return for a dependable source of straight, unbiased news for starters.

Comment: The man pardoned for the 1945 case, under today's laws, it would have been ruled self-defense. The case involved elements of the era, racism,prejudice and segregation. He did not receive adequate legal representation or a fair trial. The trial was held in Juneau, his appointed lawyer was said to be a drunkard who made no trial preparations. Any witness that the defense should have called, had left on the ship, no statements were taken. He was told if he didn't agree with the deal offered, he would be hung. 
At that time in Alaska history the only people hung between 1900 to 1945 were Alaska Natives and blacks. 
When he finally applied for a pardon, his legal team(all volunteers) had managed to find some of the men who witnessed the altercation and get sworn statements from them, and from a few of the officers still alive. In addition to the statements, his attorneys showed after being released, he married, had a family, a steady job, and lived crime-free for over 50 yrs.

Social security, food programs, healthcare, etc, are not fundamental.  Those things can be granted by government--and they can be taken away by government. We can debate whether government should cut them or take them away---but they have nothing whatever to do with pro-life/abortion.

Comment: "So far, the deployments of hydro, solar and wind energy in Canada have been made in the highest-yielding locations. ..."

Not sure that's true.

Canada has the Saudi Arabia of wind energy resources in a belt 60 miles wide EW and 250 miles log NS running from the Smallwood reservoir northward, and along the entire length of the Long Range in Newfoundland.  Canada also has enormous wind resources across Northern Quebec, from James Bay to Blanc Sablon.  None of that potential has been developed.

Wind power generation in these belts is spread over a huge geographic area.  It is almost never calm - which means power is virtually always available.

Even if it were, the region also has the largest collection of hydro reservoirs in the world.  They function as huge capacitors.

Adding wind generation to hydro has roughly the same effect as if it were raining all the time in the hydro drainage basin.

The opportunity is immense.

Comment: As I have observed, there must be limits. The risk of chaos should be the guideline as to the imposition of limits; in the case of abortion, that risk is small, but the impacts of the decision are great. We, as a nation, have honored the right of individuals to make this type of decision, even when we shudder at the result; this is consistent with my observations on free will decision making and our relationship with God. I think that we need to halt the damage that is being done by the Pro-Life faction in putting their focus on elimination choice; that has always led to practices going underground, not extinguishing practices. It would be far better to establish social constructs that encourage the choice to carry to term, and simultaneously mount a long-term campaign (not unlike the anti-smoking campaign in the US) that seeks to move public opinion to a position where abortion is not a preferred alternative. This is hard work, but it preserves autonomy while moving to a desired goal.

Comment: The report does not suggest that its conclusions are “hard science”. It explains at the beginning that if there are common threads in social science research, then those common threads are more likely to be reliable. Social science never has the reliability of “hard science” because the experiments cannot be repeated. But in ordering human affairs, we have to rely on something, as imperfect as it may be. On p 252 the report quotes the John Jay data that shows that after altar girls were introduced in 1983 “the offending rates against both altar boys and altar girls were approximately equal (Terry & Freilich 2012).” That would suggest that opportunity is a much more important factor than sexual orientation. There is a whole subchapter on the John Jay reports and its findings (which the authors do not dispute) that most abuse was with post pubescent boys. They do disagree with some other aspects of the John Jay Reports, but not the ones you mention.

Comment: There is one very compelling reason Hitler never seriously contemplated the use of poison gas against the Allies.   As a corporal  during the Great War, he suffered temporary blindness due to a British gas attack.  Like the (somewhat unjustly) maligned British Prime Minister Neville "Peace for our time" Chamberlain, even a drugged and often out-of-touch-with-reality Hitler understood how utterly catastrophic a general use of poison gas would be, especially if directed against civilian population centers such as Berlin or London.

As a side note, I had no trouble whatsoever understanding  Sean Spicer's meaning when he made his now notorious contrast between Bashar al-Assad and Adolf Hitler.  He obviously meant the deployment of chemical weapons on the field of battle - not the use of agents like Zyklon B on helpless Jews, gypsies or other Untermensch in death camps.

Histrionic politicians taking Spicer to task such as Nancy Pelosi could benefit from an evening with a good history book.

Comment: The author uses what has  become a standard word for indigenous activists, the word being listening. As a non-aboriginal I can respond to that in a number of ways. Comment: I'm a little late coming to the party on this one, but I've found this conversation fascinating. Part of the issue, I think, is that no one person or group owns the Catholic 'brand.' Even within formal Catholicism we understand the Church in multiple ways -- as institution, as hierarchy, as the People of God, as hundreds of independent legal entities (dioceses, religious orders, universities), etc. Nobody gets to speak exclusively for what it means to be Catholic.

If I'm going to defend NCR's right to call themselves 'Catholic' (and I have, many times), I should also acknowledge Church Militant's right to do the same. I have no problem with that. Intelligent people can separate the wheat from the chaff for themselves. 

But I do have a problem when the media singles out only one voice as representing "THE" Catholic perspective, which I think is the product of lazy journalism and the relentless need to feed the beast in the world of the 24-hour news cycle.

Comment: I am very suspicious of stories like this. I believe the authors have agendas and exaggerate things using inflammatory words, toxic being one frequently used/misused. Toxic has a serious meaning. It is used to describe substances and things that are life threatening. Toxic substances can kill. Its use to describe police culture is improper. 

I read stories about disgruntled individuals who may have been harassed by members of the force, mistreated by leaders, denied promotions they thought they had coming, etc. None of this amounts to toxicity to me.

Maybe the authors do not believe they can convince the public of their issues without using inflammatory words. Maybe they are poor writers, unable to express themselves convincingly, falling back on the tactics of yellow journalism.

If so maybe they should get work they are qualified for, like pushing brooms or selling shoes.

Comment: I wish the UA all the luck in the world at fund raising for the total amount of sport activity costs including costs for coaches, building construction, facilities maintenance etc... The State already $800+ million dollars or so in addition to student fees and other revenues. Divide that number by the equivalent number of full time students. Say the equivalent number of of full time students is 5000. That is $160,000/ student. 10,000 students is $80,000/ student, 15,000 students costs $53,000/year. Harvard tuition? $50,000/year.  

Divide the $800 million by 750,000 AK residents and you get the cost of the UA to every Alaskan; man woman and child. That is  $1066/ resident/year. This is about the same as what every resident lost on their PFD check this year. 

A true costs and benefit analysis anyone? Sports is not mandatory or a priority. Volunteer & donate please.

Comment: Ms. Beyak has my support in pointing out that there was also some good that came from the residential school system. It should be noted that almost all successful professional indigenous people of the past many decades came out of residential schools with a sound educational foundation on which to successfully build. In the context of the times it no doubt seemed a worthy pursuit to provide a means for indigenous people to find success in the Canadian mainstream. And it actually worked well for a significant number. That the model proved disastrous for many others, and that this should be acknowledged and compensated, is not in question. As with most issues, a balanced and objective view that identifies both negative and positive attributes is an essential part of a useful outcome. Ms Beyak should be applauded for trying to ensure that all aspects of the residential school experience are understood and recognized.

Comment: A bit of an aside here, but I believe there are too many fluff courses, including policing, that cater to young adult's job interests with little or no subsequent prospect of employment.  It's one thing to take a degree in Anthropology with the idea that job prospects are zero to none at the end of it. Everyone knows that will be the case, or should know. But it's quite another to take a course in policing, broadcasting, photography or education with no employment prospects at the end of it.  At a minimum, any post-secondary public or private course on offer in this country should be required to disclose placement rates to prospective students, for jobs in the field and jobs in general.  These rates should follow a standard format, and be subject to an audit, as part of the normal Accounting audit for the institution.  There's too much salesmanship involved in attracting students to a particular education program today.

Comment: Hatred in and of itself is not a bad thing.  It is a problem when we assign it to a person as a whole; that is, one should not hate anyone.  ON THE OTHER HAND, there are acts, behaviors, and thoughts that it is ok to hate and, indeed, should be hated.  Those act, behaviors and thoughts are called SIN.  Similarly, the word "judge" has become politically incorrect.  But it is OK to judge some acts as SINFUL.

What happens when we disallow people to hate or express hatred, we implicitly disallow sin.  
"I hate that she stole that car."  
"Stop being a hater."  

"I hate gambling"
"Why hate?"

"I think sodomy is evil"
"You're just a hater.  Stop judging."

"Hate" and "judge" have become triggers that people have knee-jerk reactions to, thanks to leftists who have made them bad words.

Comment: Denying consent is a not a "constitutional right" but a government power, which is not waived if unused.  Also, when the Framers wanted inaction to mean assent, they were specific: "“If any Bill shall not be returned by the President within ten Days (Sundays excepted) after it shall have been presented to him, the Same shall be a Law, in like Manner as if he had signed it.”  So, ugly as it is, the Senate's stance is constitutional.

Related discussion: https://www.washingtonpost.com/opinions/is-the-senates-role-in-appointments-a-right-a-duty-a-power/2016/04/13/5f4e9750-000a-11e6-8bb1-f124a43f84dc_story.html

Comment: As much as I appreciate the restaurateur intentions let's see it for what it is: marketing gimmick.

"An employee’s duty of loyalty to his employer does not mean that he cannot hold personal opinions or express his personal views. Employees can speak their mind privately or publicly on all matters that interest them.

Comment: There's no need for a scientific study on foods that humans have been eating for tens of thousands of years, but it might be a good idea to study something that is completely new because the effects on human health are unknown.  New medicines are required to undergo thorough testing before being commercialized, and GMOs  should have similar requirements.  

In the US, GMOs are tested only on animals, and not on humans.  Furthermore, most of animal tests are for only a few months.  Yet, some of those animal tests have resulted in harmful effects.  

GMOs continue to be sold on the market in the US largely because the GMO/pesticide industry spends a lot of money on lobbying.  Monsanto alone has spent an average of $6 million annually on lobbying for the past 10 years.

Comment: Actually, I do believe the fugitive should be able to seek medical attention. It is a human right to have access to medical care. I also believe that - and I am not asking you to agree with me here, to each his own opinion - an illegal immigrant who has not committed a crime, other than entering the country illegally, is not in the same position as someone who has committed a crime and has the status of fugitive. I believe that the United States has an immigration problem that needs to be resolved, but I do not believe that forcing medical authorities to disclose a person's legal status is the way to accomplish this. What I was trying to say, was that I would rather have illegal immigrants go to the hospital to help sick children, to help deliver a baby, to help cure diseases that could prove deadly if left untreated than not go for fear of deportation. I believe that deportation is a necessary aspect of curbing illegal immigration, but not at the expense of a human life.

But from a geopolitical point of view, with Trump trending towards confrontation with China, military and trade-wise, while screwing everyone else in the world, Canada should certainly explore relationships like China might offer. We should do it with our eyes wide open, and with limited expectations, but fully aware of the possibility China might take a different view of a relationship with Canada than it might have 5, 10 or 20 years ago. Like I said, Canada should watch for signs the Chinese see more value in ties with Canada because of Trump.

Comment: Dr. Kozak, your desire to improve pedestrian safety in Honolulu is laudable.  Responsibility for pedestrian safety starts first with drivers, who need to slow down, consciously look for pedestrians, obey the laws and quit rushing.  Second, pedestrians need to be alert, not distracted, and look to make eye contact with nearby drivers of cars.  Banning the use of cellphones while crossing city and state streets would certainly help.  As for intersection design, that is more of a science than an art.  Both the cities and state follow the Uniform Manual on Traffic Control Devices (MUTCD), a federal guideline which specifies when certain treatments (such as no turning movements and Barnes Dances) should be used.  Research on Barnes Dances shows they work incredibly well in some locations and horribly in others.  Cities have removed Barnes Dances where the impact on traffic congestion was severe and unjustified by pedestrian counts.   I urge the city to continue its safe pedestrian movement.

Comment: People can yowl about this all they want, however, the capital gains exemption was put in place at a time when there was much less international capital flow related to residential real estate.   

It wasn't uncommon for people to own a home 40 or so years ago and see relatively little capital appreciation on it, even after 8 to 10 years.   There was a good reason for the exemption.   Now I am not convinced this exemption makes sense anymore.

Oh - and to ease the pain, it can be phased in.   Put the first two stages in place (out to five years) and then the next two after a couple of years or so.   Someone must have some kind of data to sort this out (even if rough), and, if not, that's the first priority.

Comment: According to the  June 2016 CAPP report "Crude Oil Forecast, Markets and Transportation" on major existing and proposed crude oil pipelines exiting the WCSB (table 4.1), if Enbridge Line 3, Kinder Morgan Trans Mountain Expansion and TransCanada Keystone XL are built, the total capacity of the major pipelines exiting the WCSB will reach more than 5,812,000 barrels per day (b/d). In the same report, the CAPP estimates the total crude oil production coming from Western Canada in 2030 at 4,830,000 b/d (the Canadian Energy Research Institute estimates production at 4.7 million b/d in 2035). 
With an estimated pipeline overcapacity of almost one million barrels per day in 2030 (if the proposed pipelines are built...), EnergyEast has no future. 
More pipelines only means more GHG emissions, air and water pollution. Canada won't be able to reduce its GHG emissions unless we reduce substantially our consumption of fossil fuels. Stopping construction of new pipelines is a necessary first step.

Comment: It is common sense to practice extreme bear precautions along active salmon spawning streams anywhere in Alaska. Bears and moose are part of the Anchorage urban/wilderness interface and typically try hard to avoid you...but not always! There is far more wildlife in and around in Anchorage than most folks are aware, and many of us like that about Anchorage. Don't like it, go to the gym or the mall or inner parks. Biggest hazard, folks moving fast on wilderness trails zoned out on their music or cell phones. Need to use all your senses in the woods starting with your brain. Your brain is a far more important tool than a gun, bears can be unbelievably fast and hard to put down. Avoidance is best. I am admittedly sometimes armed in remote areas, but never around Anchorage. This is advise from a never mauled retired field geologist.

Comment: The elephant in the room on marijuana is organised crime.
.
Cap & trade is an attempt to remove the preferential treatment presently given to the fossil fuel industry.  That has been well documented, and exhaustively studied.
.
Compelling internalisation of negative externalities is one of the most important roles of government in addressing market failure.  It eliminates an implicit and capricious subsidy.  It inevitably makes markets more competitive, and richer.
.
There is broad, if not universal, consensus on that point:  In many, many years of studying economics, I have yet to see any economist argue that tolerating negative externalities is good for anybody's economy.
.
There are, however, several ways to enforce internalisation.  There is not universal consensus on which way is best.  That seems to depend on circumstances, but, generally, market-based mechanisms such as establishing a market price for the externality usually come out on top.

For example, according to Cornell University Professor David Pimentel,  it takes 13 kilograms (a kilogram is 2.2 pounds) of grain and 30 kilograms of forage to produce one kilogram of beef; 21 kilograms of grain and 30 kilograms of forage to produce a kilogram of lamb; 5.9 kilograms of grain to produce a kilogram of pork; 3.8 kilograms of grain to produce a kilogram of turkey; 2.3 kilograms of grain to produce a kilogram of chicken, and 11 kilograms of grain to produce one kilogram of eggs. Livestock in the United States consume 7 times as much grain as is consumed by the entire U.S. human population and the grains fed to livestock could feed 840 million humans who had a plant-based diet. We could end human starvation (in terms of food supply) if we all stopped eating animals.

Gary L. Francione
Professor, Rutgers University

Comment: William Blake: I think you're reflecting commonly held misconceptions about Canada's immigrant population in asserting that it's younger and healthier than the broader Canadian population. A recent Toronto Star report indicated that two-thirds of GTA seniors are immigrants, which contrasts with a 2014 report indicating that immigrants now make up just over half the GTA's population. This suggests that Canada's urban immigrant population is quickly aging, likely because a significant percentage (about one-third, according to Stats Can) of relatively young skilled immigrants leave Canada after arriving here. The Star article also notes that GTA immigrant seniors, who often speak little English, report poorer health and mental health circumstances than do their Canadian-born counterparts. The implications are ominous for the viability of our health care system.

Comment: A seven-fold increase in tanker traffic?  Perhaps true in the 25km transit of Burrard Inlet where the Kinder Morgan terminal is located.  They'll ship 35 vessels per month, up from 5; seven-fold over 25 km.   But compared to overall tanker traffic in and out of Juan de Fuca strait the increase is almost inconsequential.  At present there are 13,000 ocean going vessel transits per year.  1,100 of those are tankers with the vast majority going to Washington State refineries with Alaskan oil, (oil that was first pumped across that state by pipeline.)  Kinder Morgan expansion will add one sailing per day.  

It is this 2.77% increase in marine traffic that protesters claim will end the native way of life, (Chief Stewart Phillip,) this insignificant increase that the eco-nuts tell us will lead to the extinction of the southern resident orcas.  This small increase will lead to marine traffic congestion, and so collisions and spills.

They are not being truthful or realistic.

Comment: To us, the universe looks three dimensional. But one of the most fruitful theories of theoretical physics in the last two decades is challenging this assumption. The "holographic principle" asserts that a mathematical description of the universe actually requires one fewer dimension than it seems. What we perceive as three dimensional may just be the image of two dimensional processes on a huge cosmic horizon. In other words, there is no requirement in physics that the universe actually be three-dimensional. It could be a two-dimensional reality that only seems three-dimensional to us because of the structure of our perception capacity. If that were true (and the math of string theory points in that direction), most of our assumptions about ourselves and the world we live in would have to be false.

Comment: I feel really sad about this Washburne Wayside selloff -- With those great trees and diverse landscape, it's a beautiful natural forested  island in the middle of the agricultural  fields, and used to be one of my favorite spots to stop and take a break with my dog Koshka when driving between Eugene and Corvallis--how we loved that  great trail that ran around the periphery of the park...
It's also a significant historic site, and in 1996 when we commemorated the   Sesquicentennial of the 1846 Applegate Trail we chose that as a very special place to install historic signage depicting this protective grove  as a historic resting place  as well as  interpreting the  terrible struggles the first pioneers faced when crossing the flooded Long Tom River down the trail a few miles.
When the state ran short of funding and closed the park a few years ago we transferred that historic AT signage to the South Benton Co. museum in Monroe, right at the Long Tom crossing.
But I still miss Washburne.

Comment: A good article but I would like to raise 2 minor technical points.  You state: "Transmitter design can influence the rate of signal drop-off by focusing and directing the beam, ..."

The transmitter design has nothing with focusing and directing the beam.  That is the function of the antenna which is considered a separate element. 

The rate of signal drop off is inversely proportional to the square of the distance irrespective of beam shape.

Comment: Our corporation pays 35% federal corporate tax, 9% state corporate tax, and 7% workers' compensation. Other industrial economies usually have much lower corporate rates.

I think Trump is nuts, but this country needs tax reform badly, and if this Mad Hatter can get something through Congress, I can't imagine how it could be worse than what we now have.

Comment: Horses, like Tyrannosaurus Rex, evolved on this continent.  But that hardly makes them "native" to today's ecosystem.  A lot has changed since they become extinct nearly 10,000 years ago (depending upon which region of North America one considers).  Where wolves  and lions larger than any living on earth today once preyed upon horses, now there are only coyotes and mountain lions.  Neither is up to the task of managing horses.

Horses have no native predators except man, and when man excludes himself from this natural role they quickly outcompete native wildlife species.  If the best defense horse  advocates are able to muster is that horses are somehow "better" than cattle, then this is hardly a strong argument in their favor.  This is like saying Anthrax is better than the Plague.  Both species are highly destructive to our lands, and both require tens of millions of dollars annually in taxpayer subsidies to manage.  Rather  than bicker over which one to keep, why not eliminate both?

Comment: "Semi-automatic weapons and magazines have been around for years (decades?) prior to 1973."

Yep.

Even the evil, scary AR-15 has been available for nearly 53 years. Page 19 of the November 1964 issue of Guns magazine had a full-page advertisement from Colt for the "AR-15 Sporter". A semi-automatic rifle chambered in .223 Remington, with a 20-round magazine.

Available from any Colt dealer for $189.50 (about $1500 today, according to https://data.bls.gov/cgi-bin/cpicalc.pl). Back then, of course, it could be delivered to your door with no background check.

http://gunsmagazine.com/1964issues/G1164.pdf

Comment: All Airbnb has to do is post notification on their website that many cities now require permitting for short term rentals. As I use the service when I travel, I've noticed a photo of the permit included with some of the rentals. It implies, if you rent a unit that doesn't include the permit, there is a possibility the rental could be shut down before you arrive. Put the onus on the buyer.

On another note, after some experience with Airbnb in our strata, we created a bylaw to deal with it and they were shut down. The most recent was actually a renter who was subletting to vacationers via Airbnb, while she stayed with her boyfriend.

Comment: I would disagree on money well spent.  I spent a year in combat and taught some of these deputies after I returned from southeast Asia.  They are fine young men for the most part, but I would NEVER want them to have an assault rifle in their hands for policing the community unless the US was under full scale attack by a foreign power.  Community policing should be a civil matter and the cop/civilians need to be retrained to get rid of that 'us versus them' mentality and remember they are part of the community and NOT part of an occupying army to limit individual freedoms. 
We do a disservice to both the police and the community when we arm and train our neighbors to act like an invading army.  That kind of militarism is the way S. Vietnam leaders alienated much of the population and the viet cong became more attractive to villagers than the authoritarians.  Our current leadership is glutted with authoritarian minded bullies.
